How am I not buying things with bitcoin?
I can exchange a guitar for dollars at a pawn shop and then use those dollars to buy things, that doesn't mean I'm buying those things with a guitar. This is the exact same principle (only much quicker). Those merchants are not accepting your bitcoin for their products, they're accepting dollars; that is a very important distinction as far as bitcoin's use as an actual currency is concerned.

The Shift Card is just a convenient way to convert bitcoin to dollars, similarly with Purse you're just converting bitcoin to Amazon gift cards through a third party. In neither case are you actually buying things with the bitcoins themselves; the merchants are still getting paid in dollars.

WRITING.TITLE: Supergirl S2E20 "City of Lost Children" Episode Discussion
WRITING.TEXT:
**Synopsis:** When an alien attacks National City, Supergirl and the DEO learn the alien is a Phorian, an otherwise peaceful race with telekinetic powers. Guardian gets a lead on the Phorians address but instead of finding the culprit, he finds a very scared boy named Marcus (guest star Lonnie Chavis). Marcus will only trust James so it is up to Guardian to stop the attacks on the city. Rheas (Teri Hatcher) plan escalates.
Director: Ben Bray
Teleplay By: Gabriel Llanas Anna Musky-Goldwyn
Story By: Robert Rovner
**Main Cast:**
* Melissa Benoist as Kara Zor-El / Kara Danvers / Supergirl * Mehcad Brooks as James Olsen * Chyler Leigh as Alex Danvers * Jeremy Jordan as Winn Schott * David Harewood as J'onn J'onzz / Hank Henshaw * Chris Wood as Mon-El * Floriana Lima as Maggie Sawyer

[She's already been cast in a CBS pilot](http://deadline.com/2017/03/peyton-list-cast-cbs-drama-pilot-mission-control-frequency-season-2-1202047472/), so if that gets picked up she still won't be available.

Colbert said "cock-holster" on CBS, which you're really not allowed to do. I'm pretty sure the whole purpose of the FCC is to stop people from cursing on TV.
FCC rules only prohibit profanity between 6am and 10pm, Colbert's show isn't on during that time. The question is whether Colbert's comment is considered "obscene" by FCC rules:
For content to be ruled obscene, it must meet a three-pronged test established by the Supreme Court: It must appeal to an average person's prurient interest; depict or describe sexual conduct in a "patently offensive" way; and, taken as a whole, lack serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.
I would assume it's because of the transfer from Sardinia. In the recent past when the Giro has started in places like the Netherlands and Ireland they've done 3 days there then a rest/transfer day.

Heck, the main reason why the USA has Florida was because the Spanish needed money.
More that Spain had lost control of Florida's inhabitants (both the Seminoles and the British/American settlers) and it had been occupied by the American Army under Andrew Jackson.
Plenty of modern sovereign defaults have happened without the defaulting country having to sell off land to its creditors. Those sales typically happened due to geopolitical and/or military reasons rather than financial ones.

the producers wanted to end it and HBO did not.
This is exactly why it's a perfect example: it's a case where we know the show is ending because the producers wanted to end it, not because the network wanted to end it (i.e. cancelled it).

Netflix is paying a fraction of what the show would make if it was aired on CBS.
And that's based on what? Netflix has paid quite a lot for other shows, and again this deal with Netflix is reportedly enough to cover the show's entire budget, which means that the show doesn't have to make that much for All Access to be profitable for CBS.

Was it an expensive space show?
No, but it also didn't have Netflix paying for international distribution rights in a deal that reportedly is enough to cover the show's entire budget (I would probably take with report with a grain of salt, but still).
This isn't CBS All Access's only show, and they've already renewed their first original [scripted] show.

Why the hell is the CW showing the Dodger game at 8pm Pacific?
Because your local CW affiliate can make more money showing that than Arrow.

The timing alone tell you that this was a cancellation. When shows actually end because of the producers plan and not the network cancelling them - which is rare, particularly on broadcast - it's known well in advance. This came months after the CW picked up the show for season 8 and well after production on the season had started. Compare that to shows that are actually ending on their own terms rather than being cancelled, where the news that the show is ending comes out when the season renewal is announced if not earlier (for example, we've know GoT will end after season 8 for a while now and season 7 hasn't even aired, and HBO is on record saying they would have liked more episodes if the producers had been willing to continue). Plus if there was ever a time for TVD to naturally end it would have been after the lead actress left.
Networks are all about their PR and will do everything to avoid actually saying that a show was cancelled. But it's not hard to see through their spin.
[It was cancelled](http://tvline.com/2016/07/23/the-vampire-diaries-cancelled-season-8-ending/), the CW just made the decision before the season aired as opposed to during/after.
Series regulars still get credited even when they're not in an episode, so that doesn't mean they'll show up.

They don't cancel your shows after one season. Heck, they barely cancel shows at all.
This season the CW is nearly certain to cancel two of their three freshman series, and have already cancelled two of their veteran series.
